channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: AT&T's WarnerMedia, Discovery Discuss Merger
item.description: While AT&T has funneled resources into production for HBO Max, it's gotten rid of some other media assets.  It's a U-turn for AT&TWarnerMedia was created just three years ago through AT&T's $85 billion acquisition of Time Warner. WarnerMedia is home to storied brands including CNN, Cartoon Network, Warner Bros. AT&T is preparing to spin off its entertainment business, WarnerMedia, and merge it with competitor Discovery, Bloomberg reported yesterday.   Verizon recently sold its media assets to Apollo Global Management for $5 billion.  So why's AT&T changing course now?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Black Investors Trade Their Way Through the Pandemic
item.description: 29% of young Black Americans became first-time investors in 2020, compared to 16% of white Americans.  Because when you look at the types of people who have typically invested in stocks, Black Americans are less represented. According to the Ariel-Schwab Black Investor Survey, 63% of Black Americans under the age of 40 are now participating in the stock market, the same share as white Americans.  Here’s the lesser-known story: That surge in individual trading was led by a historic rise in the number of Black investors getting into the stock market. For Ross and Mac, it’s not surprising that cryptocurrency, with its promise to bypass entrenched financial institutions, is particularly enticing to Black investors.  For Ross and other Black Americans who grew up in disadvantaged communities (Ross is the first person in his family to graduate from high school), more access to the stock market via mobile apps means an unprecedented opportunity to grow wealth and participate in a financial system that at one point seemed so distant.  On the audio app Clubhouse, Ross Mac runs a weekly chat called Black Wealth Matters, which aims to help build “generational wealth in the Black community.”  Not having any money invested in the stock market can dramatically harm your ability to build wealth down the road. Mac, a former Wall Street analyst and financial literacy teacher, says that the pandemic has created a rush of excitement around stocks and investing among Black Americans. )Did the proliferation of no-fee trading apps contribute to the wave of new Black investors that emerged over the last year? It’s a very easy thing for us to get and understand because as a people we’ve been shut out,” Ross said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Fantasy Investing Competition Update
item.description: Bottom line: The average return among all 10,000 players was -1.51%, so if you had just sat on your initial capital and didn’t make a single trade, you’d be in pretty good shape. The most creative strategy, however, goes to writer Matty Merritt, who tripled down on her Nebraska roots with a portfolio made exclusively from corn.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Group that Hacked the Colonial Pipeline, DarkSide, Shuts Down
item.description: The criminal group DarkSide told its hacker-workers it’s shutting down. In a sign that the country still hasn’t recovered from DarkSide’s attack, Washington, DC, was crunched for gas yesterday. Looking ahead...
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: CDC’s New Guidelines Causing Confusion for Businesses
item.description: But the “mask police” assignment just got tougherPeople will still have to wear masks to patronize businesses that require them, shifting more responsibility onto workers who’ve spent more than a year on the mask beat. the CDC said masks are still advised on planes, but it will be looking at updating those guidelines along with those for daycares, summer camps, and schools.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The Group that Hacked the Colonial Pipeline, DarkSide, Shuts Down
item.description: The criminal group DarkSide told its hacker-workers it’s shutting down. It managed to do both: Following the ransomware attack, Colonial, the pipeline operator, paid DarkSide $5 million. In a sign that the country still hasn’t recovered from DarkSide’s attack, Washington, DC, was crunched for gas yesterday. Looking ahead...
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Vaccine Tracker: May 15
item.description: the head of the WHO isn’t happy about the US giving vaccines to kids.   Damn Yankees: Eight members in the NY Yankees organization have tested positive for Covid-19 despite being fully vaccinated.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: CDC’s New Guidelines Causing Confusion for Businesses
item.description: The “mask police” assignment just got tougherPeople will still have to wear masks to patronize businesses that require them, shifting more responsibility onto workers who’ve spent more than a year on the mask beat. the CDC said masks are still advised on planes, but it will be looking at updating those guidelines along with those for daycares, summer camps, and schools. But responses have been all over the board:Yesterday, Walmart said that fully vaccinated customers and employees won’t need to wear masks unless required by local laws.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Make It Work: How to Leave a Company Gracefully
item.description: Any scorched-earth actions will follow a person to future jobs. Ask Kate for advice here. I just read your response to the person looking at changing jobs. —AshleyA: Hi Ashley, I’m sorry that your experience at work has turned into a sour one. Do you have any advice on how to have that conversation gracefully? Notices longer than two weeks is an awesome look on you, too (side note: I would recommend a minimum of three weeks if you’re at the Director level or higher). And please please give your employer a two-week notice, meaning 10 full business days, at minimum. Oh!
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Barbara Corcoran
item.description: I go to the beach, and I’m always on my phone when I never used to be. That’s what I would want to have, it has never left me. I flipped the cards and said “Oh my god you’re going to get fired.” Who would ever know that that’s fun?  Yeah, I’m going to do that...  What are you into now that you never thought you would be into? I think about it a lot, I don’t know why it’s stuck in my gut. Do you think that’s true? He’s outrageous and you know you’re going to have a blast. I feel like I’m looking right into their soul. Every single card was negative I don’t think I had a worse reading, and the kid was so frightened, and what do you know two months later he was fired. When people are good with their eye contact, even if after a while they have to look down when they start getting scared, but when they initially get out there and make good eye contact, they’re always good entrepreneurs. I’m going to leave my phone in Manhattan. I’m a helluva good tarot card reader. I had no TV, no radio, no phone, and I don’t think I’ve known that degree of relaxation probably for the last 15 years. I gotta believe that if someone wants what they want is going to find a way to not have that happen. And I see right away this person is going to fold under pressure. I’m going to do that this summer. And I think life has gotten tough on people, interviewing online.  I think there’s truth in it because I know one exceptional individual who epitomizes that and that’s Mark Cuban. I will probably feel young again and relaxed.  The strangest reading I ever gave was we had a boondoggle party at my apartment, this was going back maybe four years ago, I had just hired a new social media head guy who will remain nameless. but of all those people, if someone had bad lighting, didn’t look in the camera eye, they weren’t even considered. And he said, “Could I go first?” They want a guy as a partner and that’s where it ends—and you can tell right away when they stand on that set.  How did you get into Tarot cards? And this new guy, first day on the job, we’re sitting and we had a half hour to kill and there were my tarot cards on the coffee table I said, “Hey, why don’t we read cards while we’re waiting for everyone else to come.” You know, I had the word should, but I am going to do that now.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Barbara Corcoran
item.description: And I see right away this person is going to fold under pressure.  Yeah, I’m going to do that... I’m going to leave my phone in Manhattan. I’m a helluva good tarot card reader. I went to a real estate conference at a young age and it was the first time I rented a booth, trying to hustle business straight from other brokers. I will probably feel young again and relaxed.  Yes, but even when they’re not making eye contact because they’re intimidated I’m out right away. And I’ve lived long enough to see that most of what I’ve predicted has proved out. I’m going to do that this summer. I had no TV, no radio, no phone, and I don’t think I’ve known that degree of relaxation probably for the last 15 years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Hertz Shareholders Win Big With Bankruptcy Deal
item.description: During the trading frenzy last June, Hertz topped out at $6.25 a share, which means if you were the fool who bought Hertz at its peak, you’d still have been undervaluing the company. Last June, a gang of Robinhood traders helped push the rental car’s stock up nearly 600% in less than a week, which was a curious thing to do considering the company had just filed for bankruptcy, was weighed down by nearly $19 billion in debt, and had roughly 700,000 cars parked with no one to drive them. But they were vindicatedThis week, Hertz reached a deal with a couple private equity firms to take it out of bankruptcy. He predicted “there will be no recovery for the shareholders.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Gambling Revenue Booms in Q1, Matching Records
item.description: Las Vegas is back, if you trust all the lines out the door at McCarran International Airport. US commercial casinos raked in $11.1 billion last quarter, according to the American Gaming Association, matching their best quarter ever. And both traditional and new-ish sectors of the US gambling industry are seeing the benefits. What happened?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 14
item.description: Check out their pieces on Korean adoptees being brought together by Facebook or fact-checking Modi's India. It's a big trend in the country for couples to gift each other "stock gift cards" in companies like Tesla, Apple, Amazon, and Disney.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and More to Offer Credit Cards for Consumers Without Credit
item.description: While there's no shortage of finance startups hawking credit-building apps to consumers as young as 13, a massive banking gap persists among adults: The creators of the FICO score estimate that 53 million US adults lack traditional credit scores. Big picture: For decades, a credit score was the golden ticket to a credit card.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CDC Says Fully Vaccinated People Can Ditch Masks in Most Settings
item.description: Health-care settings, buses/trains, and airplanes are all spaces you'll still have to mask up regardless of vaccine status, but the announcement is sure to push the US even further toward a full-scale reopening.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: 2020's Biggest IPOs Are Getting Smacked in the Markets
item.description: The Renaissance IPO ETF, which holds a number of public companies that IPOed within the last two years, has fallen nearly 30% from its peak in February.   Some of the biggest companies to IPO in 2020 and early 2021 are finding the public markets to be less inviting than a middle school boy’s treehouse.  Bumble: Shares in the dating company dipped below their initial price of $43 yesterday after reporting a mixed bag of earnings this week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: May 14
item.description: Check out their pieces on Korean adoptees being brought together by Facebook or fact-checking Modi's India. It's a big trend in the country for couples to gift each other "stock gift cards" in companies like Tesla, Apple, Amazon, and Disney.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 2020's Biggest IPOs Are Getting Smacked in the Markets
item.description: Some of the biggest companies to IPO in 2020 and early 2021 are finding the public markets to be less inviting than a middle school boy’s treehouse. com and mortgage insurer Enact Holdings recently delayed their IPOs because of market volatility. The Renaissance IPO ETF, which holds a number of recently public companies such as Pinterest, Coinbase, Roblox, and Slack, has fallen nearly 30% from its peak in February.  But the drooping share prices of freshly public companies is enough to spook some private firms from taking the IPO plunge.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew’s Weekly News Quiz: May 14
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and More to Offer Credit Cards for Consumers Without Credit
item.description: Big picture: For decades, a credit score was the golden ticket to a credit card. Later this year, JPMorgan Chase, US Bancorp, and Wells Fargo will join several other banks in a pilot program offering credit cards to people without credit scores, the WSJ reported.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Ark Invest Dumps Virgin Galactic Shares
item.description: Virgin Galactic was once Lord of the SPACs. In 2019, Palihapitya took Richard Branson’s space flight company public in a SPAC deal before they were cool. Some of Virgin Galactic’s biggest boosters are looking for an escape pod.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square Snaps Up 6% of Domino’s
item.description: Zoom out: This pizza party has been rocking for years.  Ackman said that he’s had his eye on Domino’s for a while, specifically watching how the company does its own delivery in the DoorDash-era.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Musk Says Tesla Will Suspend Bitcoin Payments for Its Cars
item.description: Zoom out: Tesla still has more than $1 billion in bitcoin holdings and Musk said he wouldn't sell any more. Maybe he was too busy rehearsing for SNL?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Inflation Is Rising Because the Economy Is Weird
item.description: Is this rapid inflation growth temporary? Which brings us to the question raging among economists.  So, many officials are betting that once the economy irons out the wrinkles, price growth will settle down to more typical levels. US consumer prices rose 4.2% in April from a year ago, up from the 2.6% gain in March and more than economists expected. When goodbye hugs make a comeback and the rate of inflation hits its highest level in almost 13 years. “This number was well above what I and outside forecasters expected.”
item.author: Neal Freyman
